text: He that is our God is the God of salvation; and unto GOD the Lord belong the issues from death.
text_kjv: He that is our God is the God of salvation; and unto GOD the Lord belong the issues from death.
text_niv: Our God is a God who saves;from the Sovereign Lord comes escape from death.
text_esv: Our God is a God of salvation, and to GOD, the Lord, belong deliverances from death.
text_nlt: Our God is a God who saves!The Sovereign LORD rescues us from death.
text_msg: He's our Savior, our God, oh yes!He's God-for-us, he's God-who-saves-us.Lord God knows alldeath's ins and outs.
text_nasb: God is to us a God of deliverances; And to GOD the Lord belong escapes from death.
context: Psalm 68 is a powerful hymn celebrating God's strength, majesty, and his deliverance of his people. It is a victory song, likely composed or used in connection with processions bringing the Ark of the Covenant back to Jerusalem or celebrating military victories. The psalm is rich in imagery drawn from Israel's history, particularly the Exodus and the conquest of Canaan. Verses leading up to Psalm 68:20 paint a vivid picture of God as a warrior king who scatters his enemies and establishes his reign in Zion. The psalm references God's care for the vulnerable – the fatherless, the widows – and celebrates his power to subdue even the most formidable foes. The "issues from death" would have resonated deeply with a people who had experienced miraculous deliverances from seemingly impossible situations throughout their history. They remembered God's power displayed at the Red Sea, in the wilderness, and in battles against powerful nations. The idea of God controlling the "issues from death" contrasts with the ancient Near Eastern worldview where death and the underworld were often perceived as chaotic and unpredictable forces beyond the control of the gods. This Psalm asserts Yahweh's sovereignty over life and death, a claim that was both comforting and empowering for the Israelites.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 68:20 presents a profound declaration of God's nature and attributes. "He that is our God is the God of salvation" affirms that Yahweh is not just any deity, but the God who actively saves his people. This salvation encompasses not merely physical deliverance from enemies but also spiritual redemption from sin and its consequences. The phrase "unto GOD the Lord belong the issues from death" signifies God's absolute sovereignty over life and death. The "issues from death" can be interpreted in multiple ways. It refers to God's power to rescue from physical death, as seen in the many miracles recorded in the Old Testament. It also points to God's ability to provide a way out of spiritual death, offering eternal life through faith. Furthermore, it subtly hints at the concept of resurrection, where death is not the final word but rather a gateway to a new existence in God's presence. This verse underscores the hope offered by faith in God. He is not merely a powerful being who can postpone death, but the ultimate authority who dictates its power and provides the means of overcoming it. The use of the double name "GOD the Lord" (Adonai Yahweh) emphasizes the majesty and personal connection of God. It is a reminder that the one who holds power over life and death is also the one who intimately knows and cares for his people.
application: In modern application, Psalm 68:20 offers immense comfort and hope in the face of life's inevitable challenges and losses. Recognizing God as "the God of salvation" reminds us that we are not alone in our struggles. Whether facing physical illness, emotional turmoil, or spiritual doubts, we can turn to him for deliverance. The phrase "unto GOD the Lord belong the issues from death" is especially relevant when grappling with grief and mortality. It assures us that death is not a random event, but something under God's sovereign control. This doesn't diminish the pain of loss, but it does provide a framework for understanding it within God's greater plan. We can find solace in knowing that God has the power to bring good even from the darkest experiences, and that death itself is not the end of the story. Practically, this verse challenges us to live with an eternal perspective. If God holds the keys to life and death, then our earthly concerns should be viewed in light of eternity. We should prioritize seeking God's will, living righteously, and investing in things that have eternal value. Furthermore, this verse encourages us to share the hope of salvation with others. Knowing that God is the God of salvation compels us to spread the good news of his love and redemption to those who are lost and searching. Ultimately, Psalm 68:20 calls us to trust in God's power and goodness, even when we don't understand his ways. It reminds us that he is the ultimate source of life and hope, both in this world and in the world to come.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we thank you for being the God of salvation, our refuge and strength in times of trouble. We praise you for your power over life and death, knowing that you hold all things in your hands. Lord, help us to trust in your sovereignty, even when we face difficult circumstances and losses. Grant us the peace that surpasses all understanding, knowing that you are with us always. Strengthen our faith, that we may live with an eternal perspective, seeking your will and investing in things that have eternal value. May we be bold in sharing the hope of salvation with others, that they too may come to know your love and grace. In Jesus' name, we pray. Amen.

faqs.answer: It means God has ultimate authority and control over death. He determines when and how it occurs, and He possesses the power to deliver from death, either physically or spiritually. It emphasizes God's sovereignty over life and death.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse: What does it mean that 'the issues from death' belong to God?

faqs.answer: While rooted in the Old Testament concept of God's power over death, this verse foreshadows the New Testament promise of eternal life through Jesus Christ. Jesus' resurrection demonstrates God's ultimate victory over death.
faqs.question: Q2: How does this verse relate to the concept of eternal life in the New Testament?

faqs.answer: It doesn't necessarily mean God directly causes every death, but it affirms his ultimate control and allowance. He is sovereign, even over events we may not understand or perceive as good.
faqs.question: Q3: Does this verse imply that God causes all deaths?

faqs.answer: It offers assurance that their loved one's death was not random or meaningless, but under God's sovereign care. It points towards the hope of resurrection and eternal life in God's presence. It allows us to trust God's plan.
faqs.question: Q4: How can this verse bring comfort to someone grieving the loss of a loved one?

faqs.answer: This verse directly contradicts a secular view by asserting God's active and powerful role in all aspects of life, including the most fundamental – life and death. It challenges the idea of random chance.
